comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: This hotel was mentioned by Samuel Carter Hall in A Week in Killarney (1858) and it is said to have been known as a hotel in 1840.  Slater's Commercial Directory named only three hotels in Tralee and three in Killarney in 1846 and Carter Hall named one hotel and a comfortable inn in Waterville in 1858, by which time there were seven hotels in Killarney.  They were named and their positions given by Fraser in 1854.  Some day the Tourist Board should write the history of tourism in Kerry.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Slater's Directory noted the hotels in Killarney and Tralee which were Post Houses as well and he gave the times the post carriages left for destinations such as Cahersiveen.   Cahersiveen was an important destination for commerce and a great deal of the Glenbeigh Hotel's business would have come from being a Half Way House on the way from both Tralee and Killarney. Lawrence would have known very well that he was in Glenbeigh but he possibly titled this picture in a slightly slipshod and hasty way.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosskayree] Or it may have been Robert French, Lawrence's chief photographer who got this wrong... Added your info above, and would you consider giving the history of tourism in Kerry a lash yourself??

P.S. Nice to hear from you again. You haven't been around in a while.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Hi Carol:  Thanks for the kind thoughts. The Glenbeigh Hotel enjoys good business in accommodation and food to this day and, despite the change in transportation, many locals and tourists stop there. In the days before Planning and Sustainable Development was buzzed about by everyone it is clear the owners of this hotel understood it.  Note the wide 'car park' opposite the hotel and that is there to this day.  The carriage is on its way to Tralee or Killarney and the man who got off it looks pretty snug in his long overcoat.  The other man in overcoat is reluctant to drag himself away from the woman, so the horses and carriage stand still  waiting for him in the middle of the road.  What an easygoing time it was.
